270 This study Hierarchical Co3O4 nanostructures in-situ grown on 3D nickel foam towards toluene oxidation Qi Zhang a 1 Shengpeng Mo a 1 Bingxu Chen a Weixia Zhang a Chunlei Huang a Daiqi Ye a b c ⁎ a Guangzhou, 510006, PR China. School of Environment and Energy South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 PR China 1 Shengpeng Mo and Qi Zhang are co-first authors. Graphical abstract Herein, a facile strategy for the in-situ growth of Co-based oxide precursors with unique hierarchical architectures oriented aslant or perpendicular to the Ni surfaces was reported. Toluene was chosen as probe molecule to evaluate their catalytic performance over the synthesized integrated Co-based oxide catalysts. The morphology of integrated Co-based oxide catalysts contained intercrossed frizzy nanosheets (NS), nanowires (NW), columnar nanoclusters (NC) and coral-like microspheres. The structure-performance relationship (SPR) is further confirmed via using H2-TPR, XPS, Raman spectrum. The Co3O4 NC on Ni foam exhibited the excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation (T100 = 270 °C, 50 °C lower than that of Co2AlO4 arrays with coral-like microspheres). The excellent catalytic performance of Co3O4 NC catalyst might be resulted from its lower-temperature reducibility, lattice distortion of spinel structure and abundant surface-adsorbed oxygen. The findings of this work provide a new perspective on the design of the high-efficiency integrated catalysts for VOCs combustion. Keywords Catalytic oxidation Integrated catalysts Co3O4 Ni foam Structure-performance relationship 1 Introduction With the growing daily global consumption of fossil fuels, the amount of Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in urban areas has reached much higher levels, thus air pollutants emission from transportation and industrial plants are emerging as the challenges for atmosphere and humanity [1,2]. Development of highly effective, economic, non-secondary pollution conversion technologies can completely remove hazardous VOCs. Among the various strategies proposed to degrade VOCs, catalytic oxidation (250–500 °C) is believed to be the most effective and economically feasible route for the abatement of VOCs due to low-energy consumption and less harmful reaction by-products [3,4]. The key issue of the catalytic oxidation of VOCs is rational design of high-performance catalysts with low cost and high efficiency. Although it is widely recognized that supported noble metals (i.e. Pt, Pd, Au and Ag) are effective catalysts to remove VOCs at low temperature [5–8], their high cost and susceptibility to poisoning have limited their wide and abundant industrial application. Alternatively, these transition metal oxide catalysts ((MnOx, Co3O4, CuO, Fe2O3, CeO2) have been considered as the alternative to expensive noble metal for the VOCs oxidation due to relatively low cost, strong oxygen storage/release ability [9–15]. Among these transition metal oxide catalysts, tricobalt tetraoxide (Co3O4) has attracted much attention due to its low cost-efficiency, environmental benignity, and relatively high catalytic activity in numerous reactions, e.g., the carbon monoxide (CO) [16–18], nitric oxide (NO) [19,20], hydrocarbon (CxHy) oxidation as well as soot combustion [21–23]. For many heterogeneous reactions, it is well known that rational design and synthesize of Co3O4 nanomaterials with preferred porous structure, sizes and morphologies (e.g. nanorods, nanowires, nanobelts and nanocubes) is efficient ways of increasing catalyst activity and selectivity [10,16,21,24,25]. For instance, Xie et al. [16] reported that the Co3O4 nanorods with predominantly exposed their (110) planes calcined at 450 °C could catalyse CO oxidation at temperatures as low as −77 °C at a SV of 15,000 mL h−1 gcat −1. Li et al. [10] prepared a series of mesoporous Co3O4 catalysts by the acid treatment, and the acid-treated Co3O4 catalysts using lower HNO3 concentrations exhibited the optimum catalytic toluene activity (T90 = 225 °C) and excellent catalytic durability. Our group previously synthesized three-dimensional (3D) hierarchical Co3O4 nanocatalysts with different morphology and various exposed crystal planes, it could be found that 3D hierarchical cube-stacked Co3O4 microspheres achieved a toluene conversion of 90% (T90) of approximately 248 °C [25]. These researches suggested that the design and synthesis of catalysts contribute to improving the catalytic activity, whereas the above researches focus on the study of powder catalysts. Taking into accounting the practical application of powder catalysts, how to achieve large-scale preparation and practical application of such Co3O4 nanomaterials with tunable morphologies is of vital importance and remains a challenging goal. The conventional powder catalysts are usually introduced onto the surface or mixed into the channel walls of a structured support (e.g. ceramic or metallic substrate) by wash-coating, wet-impregnation or extrusion, which are always inhomogeneous and easy to aggregate, and have a negative effect on the practical application of the monolithic catalysts [26–28]. Therefore, some efforts have been devoted to grow nanoarray-based catalysts on channeled monolithic substrates to promote catalytic activity [26,29,30]. As compared to ceramic monoliths, nickel (Ni) foam has distinguished features such as low cost, a three-dimensional (3D) reticular configuration, rich accessible electroactive sites, high thermal conductivity and desired mechanical strength, and high surface area to volume, which has been attracting sustained attention in the applications of lithium-ion batteries [31], energy storage [32,33], and catalysis [19]. Zhao et al. [32] fabricated successfully MnCo2O4@Ni(OH)2 multicomponent core-shell nanoflowers supported on the 3D macroporous nickel foam substrate for the first time by a facile and cost-effective method, which exhibits a significantly enhanced specific capacitance (2154 F g−1 at 5 A g−1). Liu et al. [19] developed a hierarchical MnO2@NiCo2O4 core-shell nanowire arrays in situ grown on the nickel surface serving as a promising candidate for the monolith de-NOx catalyst. Therefore, these works inspired us to construct well-defined Co3O4 nanoarray-based catalysts on porous nickel (Ni) foam for the application of toluene oxidation. In this work, we try to consider that a series of Co-based oxide arrays were synthesized via in-situ growth on porous nickel foam with different morphology, and further investigated their catalytic performances for toluene oxidation. The phase compositions, surface elemental states and catalytic performances of catalysts were investigated by numerous techniques to better understand the impact of the morphological transformation on their physicochemical properties, thus further confirming the structure-activity relationship. To the best of our knowledge, rarely previous work has reported the catalytic behaviors of well-defined Co3O4 array catalysts on porous nickel (Ni) foam for VOCs oxidation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of Co3O4 NS on Ni foam The cleaned Ni foam (approximately 5 cm × 7 cm, thickness 1.6 mm and pore density 110 ppi) was put against the 50.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave which contained a homogeneous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol), urea (8 mmol) and a 40 mL mixed solvent of ethanol/ethanol (Vethanol:Vmethanol = 40:40). The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 95 °C for 12 h to synthesize the precursor in an electric oven. The sample was rinsed several times and dried in air at 80 °C. Finally, the Ni foam with the as-grown precursor was annealed at 350 °C for 3 h. The as-prepared catalyst is denoted as Co3O4 NS. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Co3O4 NW on Ni foam The cleaned Ni foam was put against the 50.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave which contained a homogeneous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol), urea (8 mmol), polyethylene glycol (PEG-6000) (0.3 g) and 40 mL water. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 95 °C for 12 h in an electric oven. Finally, the as-grown precursor was put into a quartz tube and then annealed at 350 °C for 3 h. The as-prepared catalyst is denoted as Co3O4 NW. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Co3O4 NC on Ni foam The cleaned Ni foam was put against the 50.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave which contained a homogeneous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol), urea (8 mmol), Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP-K30, 0.3 g) and 40 mL water. The autoclave maintained at 95 °C for 8 h and then raised the temperature to 110 °C for 5 h in an electric oven. Finally, the as-grown precursor was put into a quartz tube and then annealed at 350 °C for 3 h. The as-prepared catalyst is denoted as Co3O4 NC. 2.1.4 Synthesis of Co2AlO4 on Ni foam The cleaned Ni foam was put against the 50.0 mL Teflon-lined autoclave which contained a homogeneous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (2 mmol), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (1 mmol), urea (8 mmol) and 40 mL water. The autoclave was sealed and maintained at 95 °C for 12 h in an electric oven. Finally, the as-grown precursor was put into a quartz tube and then annealed at 350 °C for 3 h. The as-prepared catalyst is denoted as Co2AlO4. 2.1.5 Synthesis of WI-Ni foam and WI-honeycomb substrate Firstly, a solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (4 mmol) dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water was produced. Secondly, the Ni foam and honeycomb substrate were put against the nitrate salt solution, respectively. And then NH4OH (water solution 25%) was added dropwise to the nitrate salt solution, keeping at a constant pH value of 9.0. After 6 h at room temperature, the samples were collected. Finally, the as-grown precursors were put into a quartz tube and then annealed at 350 °C for 3 h. The as-prepared catalysts are denoted as WI-Ni foam and WI-honeycomb substrate. 2.2 Materials characterizations X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the monolithic structured samples were recorded on a Panalytical X'Pert PRO system with Cu-Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation at a scan rate of 10 min−1 within the range of scattering angle 2θ of 5–90°, operated at 40kv and 40 mA. The size and morphology of samples were characterized using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM-6700F) with an acceleration voltage of 15 kV, 10 mM. The microstructures of samples were obtained using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOLJEM-2010F) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The reduction behavior of the samples was studied by the temperature–programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2–TPR) with Automated Catalyst Characterization System (Autochem 2920, MICROMERITICS) equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The monolithic structured Co3O4 array sample (1 cm × 3 cm × 1.6 mm) was placed in a quartz reactor under a gas flow (10% H2/Ar, 25 mL min−1) with a constant rate of 10 °C min−1 up to 800 °C. The Raman spectra of the monolithic samples were conducted on a Renishaw RM2000 Raman Spectrometer (laser wavelength = 532 nm). Surface species of the catalysts were characterized by X–ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an XLESCALAB 250Xi electron spectrometer from VG Scientific with monochromatic Al Ka radiation, and the binding energies of elements were calibrated based on the C 1s peaks at 284.6 eV. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The as-prepared Co3O4 catalysts (1 cm × 4 cm × 1.6 mm, about 0.1450 g) buckling into a cylinder were evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz tubular micro-reactor (φ = 6 mm) with quartz wool packed at both ends of the catalyst bed (gas hourly space velocity = 20,000 h−1). The reactant gas composed of 1000 ppm toluene balanced with air (20 vol.% O2 + balance N2) was purged into the reactor at a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. After reacted at the final temperature for 1 h, the concentrations of effluent gases were analyzed on-line by a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with two flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology Fig. 1 (a–h) shows field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) images of the as-prepared Co2AlO4 and Co3O4 arrays on the Ni foam with nanosheet (NS), nanowire (NW) and nanocluster (NC). The top-view FESEM image of pristine Ni foam substrate in Fig. 1i shows that Ni foam has an interconnected porous framework, providing effective accessible channels for the support and the growth center of powder catalysts with strong adhesion. As shown in Fig. 1a and b, it can be clearly seen that the as-synthesized Co3O4 NS displayed frizzy nanoflake structure with a slightly curved lateral dimension of approximately 1.0–2.0 μm, almost no ab-faces and slightly intercrossed with each other, and it grew uniformly vertical to the Ni foam forming a highly dense film with strong adhesion, covering the entire surface of the Ni foam. The FESEM images (Fig. 1c and d) of Co3O4 NW sample indicated that nanowire arrays vertically grown on Ni foam have appeared, and the width dimensions were approximately 200–300 nm. From the SEM images of Co3O4 NC in Fig. 1(e and f), it was observed that the thin nanowires with interconnected with each other were uniformly distributed on the Ni foam ligament surface, forming a series of columnar nanoclusters. Meanwhile, it is seen from Fig. 1(g and h) that the morphology of Co2AlO4 sample presented hierarchical coral-like microspheres and/or pompom-like frizzy nanoflakes with a diameter of 1.5–3.0 μm that resembled a large quantity of densely packed and interlaced nanoplatelets. On average, the mass loading of per unit area over the Co-based samples were about 3.1–3.5 mg on a circular disk of Ni foam (Table 1 ). The conditions for hydrothermal synthesis varied between each method, the mass of Co2+ ions was excessive in the reaction bath, therefore the mass loadings of the Co-based samples owned the same amounts of powder Co3O4. 3.2 XRD analysis Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of as-prepared Co3O4 NS, NW, NC and Co2AlO4 samples. There were three sharp diffraction peaks at 44.8°, 52.1°, and 76.6° in each spectrum, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of pure Ni metal substrate (JCPDS card no. 65-2865), respectively. The positions of diffraction peaks of all samples were rather similar. For Co2AlO4 sample, besides the peaks originating from the Ni substrate, there were six diffraction peaks at 19.1°, 31.4°, 36.9°, 38.3°, 59.2°, and 65.1°, respectively, which belonged to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (511), and (440) planes and was well matched with spinel oxide phases (Co2AlO4, JCPDS card no. 38-0814; CoAl2O4, JCPDS card no. 44-0160). The diffraction peaks of another three Co3O4 array samples were perfectly assigned to pure face-centered cubic phase of Co3O4 (JCPDS card no. 42-1467). It was rather difficult to distinguish between Co2AlO4 and Co3O4 spinels via XRD due to their almost identical diffraction positions. Both Co3+ and Al3+ cations occupy tetrahedral or octahedral lattice sites, thus Co3+ can be replaced by Al3+ to from stable Co2AlO4 spinel phase [23]. 3.3 Surface area analysis Fig. 3 displays the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms for as-synthesized Co-based samples. Before the tests, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h. The isotherms are consistent with type IV isotherms with a H2-type hysteresis loop in the relative pressure ranges (p/po ), which are associated with capillary condensation taking place in mesopores. The BET data of Co-based samples are listed in Table 1. The surface area and pore volume of the uncoated Ni foam are 24.85 m2 g−1 and 0.064 cm3 g−1, respectively. Compared to the pure Ni foam, it can be found that there are slightly increased in the surface areas of Co-based catalysts (27.49 m2 g−1 to 48.88 m2 g−1), and the pore volumes increased slightly in the ranges of 0.131–0.187 cm3 g−1. It is noticeable that the Co3O4 NC possessed largest surface area and pore volume among the Co-based catalysts. 3.4 Microstructure To further reveal microstructures of Co3O4 NS, NW and NC samples, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurement was carried out, with the results shown in Fig. 4 . Both Co3O4 array samples scraped off from the Ni foam can maintain the primary shapes. As shown in Fig. 4a, the Co3O4 NS was composed of a randomly aggregated structure of ultrathin frizzy nanosheets with flattened surfaces. The HRTEM image (Fig. 4b) of Co3O4 NS revealed that there were two lattice fringes about 0.203 nm and 0.286 nm, which were derived from the (400) and (220) crystal faces of pure Co3O4, respectively. There is an angle of 45° between (400) and (220) crystal face, which demonstrates that the Co3O4 NS dominantly exposed {100} surfaces. Form the TEM image of Co3O4 NW (Fig. 4c), the morphology showed a bunch of nanowires, and the width dimensions were approximately 200 nm in agreement with in Fig. 1(c and d), and the surface lattice spacing in Fig. 4d was measured to be 0.467 nm corresponding to the (110) crystal plane of Co3O4, indicating the nanowire was along [110] direction. The morphology of Co3O4 NC was composed of nanowires to form nanoclusters with flattened surfaces, and the individual nanowires were also composed of a number of tiny particles (Fig. 4e). The width and length dimensions were approximately 200 nm and 3.0 μm, respectively. From high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Co3O4 NC in Fig. 4f, there were two lattice fringes about 0.243 nm and 0.284 nm, which were derived from the (311) and (220) crystal faces of pure Co3O4, respectively. The thin nanowires of columnar nanoclusters can preferentially expose {110} surfaces. What is more, it can be seen that several ledges on the surface of Co3O4 NC sample were observed (Fig. 4f), demonstrating the presence of abundant surface defect sites. Additionally, the active sites resulted from exposed surfaces or growth orientation of crystal structures [25]. According to previous studies [34–36], the (100) and (111) planes contain only Co2+ cation, whereas the highly reactive (110) plane presents 5 Co2+ and 4 Co3+ in one unit cell. Therefore, the Co3O4 nanowires exposed {110} facets would show higher catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, especially Co3O4 NC with abundant surface defect sites. 3.5 Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) Low-temperature reducibility of catalysts is an important factor influencing its surface oxygen reactivity, surface reaction sites and related catalytic performances in Mars-van Krevelen (redox) mechanism. Herein, hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out to determine different forms and reduction behaviors in monolithic samples, as shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that the Co3O4 NS presented two overlapping H2 consumption peaks with the maximum rates of H2 consumption located at 271 and 308 °C, respectively, which was ascribed to a stepwise process via the sequence of Co3+ → Co2+ → Co0 [23].The low-temperature reduction behaviors of Co3O4 NW and NC catalysts were similar to that of Co3O4 NS in terms of their stepwise process despite the different H2 consumptions. The Co3O4 NW sample was reduced in two main temperature regions, and the maximum rate of H2 consumption for the reduction of the Co3O4 phase occurred at 284 and 305 °C, respectively. For Co3O4 NC sample, two overlapping H2 consumption peaks at 286 and 315 °C were observed, and there were the reduction peak area of Co3+ reduction. In the case of Co2AlO4 sample, there were three asymmetrical and/or separate reduction peaks in a temperature range 100–700 °C. The first two peaks in the low temperature range of 250–350 °C were attributed to the reduction of Co3+ into Co2+, and the further reduction of Co2+ to metallic cobalt, respectively. The third broad peak in the low temperature range of 400–700 °C was associated with the further reduction of large cobalt-containing spinel particles, in which Co2+ and Co3+ ions in spinel phases can interact with neighboring groups through the CoO bonds polarized by Al3+ (with the formation of CoAl2O4 or Co2AlO4 phases) [37]. According to the H2-TPR results, the first reduction peak of Co3O4 NC revealed a largest peak area than those of other array samples, which was generally recognized as a sign of the improved reducibility of Co3+ to Co2+ caused by the exposed percentage of surface Co3+ species. And the exposed {110} facets of Co3O4 NC were benefited for better low-temperature reducibility, in agreement with the TEM results. Nevertheless, the hindered reduction of cobalt species on the Co2AlO4 sample was ascribed to the formation of cobalt aluminium oxide phases, suggesting that a negative effect on the low-temperature reducibility was induced by Al3+ species, which was in good agreement with the XRD result of Co2AlO4 sample. These results implied the different distribution proportions of Co3+ and Co2+ in monolithic samples, and the morphological transformation tended to induce more surface Co3+ species playing an significant role on the oxidation of toluene, since the oxidation of VOCs proceed via a Mars-van Krevelen (redox) mechanism. 3.6 Structural defects Raman spectroscopy is an intriguing tool to analyze the structural properties (lattice distortion) of Co-based oxide arrays. Fig. 6 displays the Raman spectra of as-prepared monolithic Co-based samples, and five Raman-active modes (A1g + Eg + 3F2g) were observed. In the case of the Co2AlO4 sample, five Raman bands locate at 196, 523, 625, 484 and 695 cm−1, were assigned to the 3F2g, Eg and A1g Raman active modes of Co3O4 nanocrystals, respectively [38]. The weak peaks located at approximately 196, 523, 625 cm−1 can be attributed to the characteristics of tetrahedral sites (CoO4), whereas the peak located at 695 cm−1 can be attributed to the characteristics of the symmetric Co3+ O (octahedral CoO6 sites) stretching vibration. The Co3O4 NC displayed the five Raman peaks located at 188, 516, 619, 478 and 683 cm−1, respectively. In comparison to the Co3O4 NS and Co2AlO4 sample, the peak positions of five active modes of Co3O4 NC shifted to lower wave numbers by 5–15 cm−1, suggesting that polyhedral distortion occurring in the spinel lattice has influenced on the original coordinative environment of octahedral sites, in which Co2+ and Co3+ cations are situated at tetrahedral and octahedral sites in the cubic lattice of Co3O4 [38]. This red-shift phenomenon indicated the idea of the more crystal defects beneficial for giving rise to surface oxygen vacancies [23,39], in addition, and the presence of crystal defects have been confirmed by the HRTEM result in Fig. 4f. 3.7 Surface element composition X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) measurements were performed to probe the surface chemical states and adsorbed oxygen species of as-prepared Co-based catalysts, as shown in Fig. 7 . To get further insight into the surface properties, the Co 2p3/2 spectra could be further deconvoluted into two components peaks at binding energy (BE) = 779.9 ± 0.2 and 781.1 ± 0.2 eV, and two weak shake-up satellite peaks [23,40]. The peaks located at 779.9 and 781.1 eV could be assigned to Co3+ and Co2+oxidation states, respectively. The other peaks at higher binding energy of 784.8 ± 0.2 and 788.2 ± 0.2 eV were associated with the shake-up satellite of Co3+ and Co2+, respectively. The surface Co3+/Co2+molar ratios were determined based on the area fitted curve peaks on Co 2p3/2 XPS spectra and are listed in Table 1. It could be found that the surface Co3+/Co2+ (1.69) atomic ratio of the Co3O4 NC sample was obviously highest than those (1.08–1.37) of the other Co-based samples, indicating that relatively more Co3+ species presented. Whereas the Co2AlO4 sample possessed lower Co3+/Co2+ (1.08) atomic ratio due to the formation of CoAl2O4 or Co2AlO4 phases on the bulk. The increased Co3+/Co2+ molar ratio on the surface acted as the active site for toluene oxidation can actively take part in the catalytic process, and result in a charge imbalance which can be confirmed by the fine-scanned O 1s XPS spectra. As for the O 1s XPS spectra of Co-based samples, the signals for each catalyst can be decomposed into two components, lattice oxygen species (OI) (∼529.3 eV for O2–), highly oxidative oxygen species (OII) (∼531.6 eV for O2 −, O− or OH) [11,23]. Obviously, the Co3O4 NC sample exhibited the relatively higher area of OII peak, further indicating the presence of oxygen vacancies on the surface of Co3O4 NC. The surface OII/OI atomic ratio increased in the following order: Co3O4 NC > Co3O4 NW > Co2AlO4 > Co3O4 NS. The increased concentration of surface or chemisorbed oxygen (OII) would benefit the catalytic toluene performance of Co-based oxide catalysts. The result reveals that the exposed {110} facets also were benefited for surface Co3+/Co2+ and OII/OI atomic ratio of Co3O4 NC, confirmed by the Co 2p and O 1s results. 3.8 Catalytic activity measurement Fig. 8 a shows the toluene conversion curves of the as-prepared integrated Co-based oxide catalysts (1 cm × 4 cm × 1.6 mm) with increasing reaction temperature under a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 20,000 h−1, all the as-prepared catalysts displayed positive toluene conversion with the only CO2 and water products, and other intermediate oxidation products were not monitored on line by a gas chromatograph. To conveniently compare the catalytic activities of the integrated Co-based oxide catalysts, the catalytic activities of these catalysts were compared based on the values of T10, T50 and T100 (the temperatures corresponding to the 10, 50 and 100% conversion of catalytic toluene combustion) as a reference, which were summarized in Table 1. The Ni foam and honeycomb substrate loading Co3O4 were synthesized by wet-impregnation method, the as-prepared catalysts are denoted as WI-Ni foam and WI-honeycomb substrate, respectively. The WI-Ni foam and WI-honeycomb substrate catalysts showed the completely catalytic activities of toluene oxidation at 320 and >350 °C, respectively. The Co2AlO4 catalyst prepared by the hydrothermal synthesis also showed the relatively lower catalytic activity, its T10, T50 and T100 were achieved at 290, 313 and 320 °C, respectively. Nevertheless, the Co3O4 NC catalyst displayed the best catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, with the complete toluene conversion at 270 °C. And the T50 and T100 values for toluene oxidation over the Co3O4 NC were 49 and 50 °C lower than those achieved over the Co2AlO4 catalyst, respectively. Specifically, it can be deduced that the following activity trend of four catalysts was observed in the order: Co3O4 NC > Co3O4 NW > Co3O4 NS > Co2AlO4. The Co3O4 NW, Co3O4 NS and Co2AlO4 catalysts had very lower activity (<20%) when the temperature was even as high as 270 °C, whereas at the same temperature, the toluene conversion of Co3O4 NC can completely catalyse toluene degradation. Fig. 8b shows the reaction rate of all Co-based oxide catalysts at 270 °C. The reaction rate of the Co3O4 NC at 270 °C was about 53.38 × 10−4 mol gcat −1 h−1, which was clearly greater than those of other samples. Fig. 8c shows the catalytic performances of the Co3O4 NC catalysts with different calcination temperature (350, 450 and 550 °C). It is obvious that the Co3O4 NC(350) catalyst obtained at 350 °C exhibits the highest catalytic activity among all Co3O4 NC catalysts, achieving complete toluene conversion at about 270 °C, and whose T100 is 20 °C lower than that achieved over the Co3O4 NC(550). The effects of GHSV on the catalytic activities of the Co3O4 NC sample for toluene oxidation were further evaluated following the slight decrease with the rise in GHSV value, as shown in Fig. 8d. Under the condition of GHSV = 10,000 h−1, the corresponding temperature for 100% conversion was about 250 °C. These results suggested that the morphology of arrays in-situ grown on Ni foam can improve the catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. Since the best-performing Co3O4 NC catalyst owned the best catalytic reactivity among all catalysts, the Co3O4 NC catalyst was selected as a model catalyst for long-term durability tests under dry and moist conditions, as shown in Fig. 9 . The toluene conversions of 100% and 61% maintained constant without any deactivation under dry conditions at 272 and 265 °C during the activity test for 36 h. For practical applications of VOCs oxidation catalysts, the inevitable presence of moisture in an ambient environment has been known to exert a great influence on the catalytic activity of a catalyst for VOCs oxidation. When 1.5 vol.% H2O was introduced into the stream at 272 °C, the toluene conversion decreased from 100% to 90% during the activity test for 12 h, whereas the toluene conversion decreased sharply from 100% to 70% with the addition of higher concentration (5 vol.%) of moisture. Once the moisture was stopped, the activity was rapidly increased back to its original level (100% toluene conversion). This indicates that moisture indeed caused a sudden deactivation of toluene catalytic combustion in our current study, in which the surface of the catalyst was inhibited by moisture and there were the competitive adsorption of water and target molecules on the surface active sites [10,41]. Most importantly, the Co3O4 NC catalyst exhibited the good regeneration ability and stability. Additionally, Table 2 summarizes the catalytic activities for VOCs oxidation over monolithic catalysts previously reported by other researchers [4,42–51]. Despite the different reaction conditions, the as-prepared Co3O4 NC catalyst with aligned nanoclusters in this work presented an outstanding activity for toluene oxidation. Thus, the macropore walls of Ni foam substrates are beneficial to the formation of a 3D macroporous network of Co3O4, which not only exhibits good mass transfer properties toward reactant molecules, but increases their contact with surface sites. It has been accepted that the catalytic activity of a transition metal oxide for VOCs oxidation can be greatly influenced by several factors, such as surface area, morphology, surface active species, structure defects and reducibility of catalyst. Moreover, it is widely accepted that the Mars-Van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism has been widely used to illustrate the VOCs combustion mechanism on the surface of catalysts [49]. According to the catalytic and characterization analyses, the Co3O4 NC composed of a series of columnar nanoclusters showed the highest catalytic activity for toluene oxidation, and highest reaction rate (53.38 × 10−4 mol gcat −1 h−1) at 270 °C. However, the Co3O4 NW, Co3O4 NS and Co2AlO4 catalysts had very lower activity when the temperature was even as high as 270 °C, whereas at the same temperature, the toluene conversion of Co3O4 NC can completely catalyse toluene degradation. This catalytic test results suggested the morphology resulted from exposed surfaces or growth orientation of crystal structures may play a key role in toluene oxidation. Furthermore, the Co3O4 NC possessed largest surface area among the Co-based catalysts. And the exposed facets determine the surface Co3+ species, oxygen species and low-temperature reduction behaviors. The XPS confirmed that Co3O4 NC catalyst possessed the more surface Co3+ species, inducing the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies (OII/OI = 0.871). It is known that oxygen vacancies can actively take part in the oxidation process (the adsorption, activation and migration of oxygen species) and greatly contribute to the catalyst activity. This redox mechanism supposes that the catalytic VOCs oxidation consists of two successive steps [41,52]: (1) the adsorption of reactants with the surface adsorbed oxygen species to transfer it to CO2 and water; (2) the oxygen molecules (O2) are activated to become the surface adsorbed oxygen species and the redox couple Co3+/Co2+ simultaneously take place. Therefore, the abundant surface oxygen vacancies may be benefited for the increased concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen and increased reaction rate for VOCs oxidation. According to MVK redox mechanism, excellent low-temperature reducibility would offer higher performance of the catalyst. According to the H2-TPR results, Co3O4 NC reveals a largest peak area (Co3+ to Co2+) than those of other array samples, which caused by the exposed percentage of surface Co3+ species. Nevertheless, the hindered reduction of cobalt species on the Co2AlO4 sample was ascribed to the formation of cobalt aluminium oxide phases. Thus, both Co3O4 NC and Co2AlO4 samples displayed the significant difference of catalytic performance for toluene oxidation, leading to a low-temperature reduction behavior confirmed by H2-TPR investigation. Furthermore, the structural defects of a catalyst are also beneficial for greater amounts of surface oxygen vacancies. It could be seen that a presence of abundant surface defect sites on the surface of Co3O4 NC sample are observed by HRTEM. And the peak positions of five active modes of Co3O4 NC shifted to lower wave numbers by 5–15 cm−1, its red-shift phenomenon implied the idea of polyhedral distortion in the spinel lattice giving rise to surface oxygen vacancies. The presence of surface oxygen vacancies has been confirmed by the O 1s XPS result. Hence, we could propose that the morphological transformation of Co3O4 arrays tended to induce the difference of surface adsorbed oxygen species, Co3+ species and redox behavior of the catalyst, bringing a significant improvement of catalytic toluene combustion. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, advanced monolithic Co-based oxide catalysts have been successfully synthesized through a generic hydrothermal synthesis route to in situ grow highly ordered Co3O4 arrays onto Ni substrates. The morphology of monolithic Co-based oxide catalysts contained intercrossed frizzy nanosheets (NS), nanowires (NW), nanoclusters (NC) and coral-like microspheres. The catalytic oxidation of toluene as the model reaction was further used to evaluate their catalytic performances of monolithic Co-based oxide catalysts. Based on the catalytic and characterization analyses, it can be found that the Co3O4 NC composed of a series of columnar nanoclusters exhibited excellent catalytic performance for toluene oxidation, and highest reaction rate (53.38 × 10−4 mol gcat −1 h−1) at 270 °C. The catalytic performance was associated with the surface adsorbed oxygen species (OII/OI = 0.871), more surface Co3+ species, high low-temperature reducibility and the structural defects. Most importantly, the Co3O4 NC catalyst exhibited the good regeneration ability and stability. Thus, the Ni foam substrates are beneficial to the formation of a 3D macroporous network of Co3O4, which is significant for the development and practical use of integrated catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Herein, a facile strategy for the in-situ growth of Co-based oxide precursors with unique hierarchical architectures oriented aslant or perpendicular to the Ni surfaces was reported. Toluene was chosen as probe molecule to evaluate their catalytic performance over the synthesized integrated Co-based oxide catalysts. The morphology of integrated Co-based oxide catalysts contained intercrossed frizzy nanosheets (NS), nanowires (NW), columnar nanoclusters (NC) and coral-like microspheres. The structure-performance relationship (SPR) is further confirmed via using H2-TPR, XPS, Raman spectrum. The Co3O4 NC on Ni foam exhibited the excellent catalytic activity for toluene oxidation (T100 = 270 °C, 50 °C lower than that of Co2AlO4 arrays with coral-like microspheres). The excellent catalytic performance of Co3O4 NC catalyst might be resulted from its lower-temperature reducibility, lattice distortion of spinel structure and abundant surface-adsorbed oxygen. The findings of this work provide a new perspective on the design of the high-efficiency integrated catalysts for VOCs combustion.
coredata.dc:title: Hierarchical Co3O4 nanostructures in-situ grown on 3D nickel foam towards toluene oxidation
